data.text: Rāma, as described in the Skanda Purana, is a multifaceted divine figure with numerous roles and attributes. He is the son of Daśaratha and a key member of the Raghu clan, renowned for his valor and righteousness. As an incarnation of Viṣṇu, Rāma is celebrated for his heroic deeds, particularly his battle against Rāvaṇa, the construction of the bridge known as Setu, and his subsequent installation of the divine Liṅga Rāmanātha on Rāmasetu

data.text:
Rāma, also known as Paraśurāma, is a noble-souled sage and warrior from the Bhṛgu family, renowned for his mastery of the Vedas, scriptures, and various weapons, including the Kavaca and Mantra given by Śiva. According to the Brahmanda Purana, he upholds dharma by serving his parents and visiting his grandfather's house with permission [1], and is advised by Bhṛgu to perform penance and travel to the Himavān [2]. He is described as performing severe penance and being tested by Lord Śiva in the form of a hunter [3], and receives boons from Śambhu, including protection against enemies and the ability to control his vital airs [4]. After his father Jamadagni's murder, Rāma vows to destroy the Kṣatriya caste twenty-one times [5], and seeks vengeance against Kārttavīryārjuna for insulting his father, engaging in fierce battles and defeating many kings, including Kārttavīrya, using various divine missiles and physical combat [6][7][8][9][10]. He is also known for capturing twelve thousand kings and performing rituals at Kurukṣetra to honor his parents [11], reclaiming land from the sea by convincing Varuṇa to withdraw his waters and restore the holy spot of Gokarṇa for the sages [12], and eulogizing the Supreme Lord while seeking blessings from deities including Śiva, Pārvatī, and Kṛṣṇa [13]. Additionally, Rāma is the son of Jamadagni and Reṇukā, known for mastering archery and killing Kṣatriyas [14], and is mentioned as the husband of Sītā, known for his virtuous qualities [15].

data.text:
Rama, the eldest son of King Dasaratha and Queen Kaushalya, is depicted as a virtuous, valorous, and wise prince of the Ikshvaku dynasty, born with numerous virtues including compassion, wisdom, and valor as described by Shri Narada in the Ramayana, Bala Kanda, Chapter 1 [1]. According to the Ramayana, Bala Kanda, Chapter 2, Rama is the central figure whose story is narrated by Sage Valmiki as commanded by Brahma, and is described as the essence of virtue and full of the highest attributes [2]. In Bala Kanda, Chapter 3, Rama is depicted as a virtuous and righteous prince whose life, from his valorous deeds to his benevolence and truthfulness, is narrated by Sage Valmiki [3]. 

In Bala Kanda, Chapter 19, Rama is described as a son of Dasaratha whose virtues are known to sages and who is destined to destroy the rakshasas troubling Vishvamitra [4]. According to Bala Kanda, Chapter 23, Rama is one of the princes who performs his morning devotions and visits the hermitage of Kama with Lakshmana, seeking guidance from Sage Vishvamitra [5]. In Bala Kanda, Chapter 25, Shri Rama is a prince of limitless power who is approached by Shri Vishvamitra to perform a righteous duty of slaying the demon Taraka [6]. 

In Ayodhya Kanda, Chapter 2, Rama is praised for his numerous virtues such as righteousness, wisdom, and bravery, making him the ideal candidate for regent [7]. According to Ayodhya Kanda, Chapter 4, Rama is the lotus-eyed prince who is to be installed as successor by his father King Dasaratha upon the advice of astrologers [8]. In Ayodhya Kanda, Chapter 5, Rama welcomed his preceptor Vasishtha and followed his advice to observe a fast before his coronation, as planned by his father, King Dasaratha [9]. 

After being exiled by Kaikeyi's demand, Rama, according to Ayodhya Kanda, Chapter 11, is described as 'invincible' and 'dearer than life' to Dasaratha, yet Kaikeyi demands his exile for fourteen years [10]. In Ayodhya Kanda, Chapter 19, Rama maintains composure and determination in the face of his exile, highlighting his unwavering commitment to dharma and service to his father [11]. According to Ayodhya Kanda, Chapter 20, Rama, after receiving his mother's blessing, informs her about his impending exile to the Dandaka forest for fourteen years [12]. 

In Aranya Kanda, Chapter 1, Rama is welcomed by the Sages of the Dandaka Forest and is described as an invincible, master of his senses, who enters the Dandaka Forest and is greeted with reverence by the ascetics [13]. According to Aranya Kanda, Chapter 17, Rama is the eldest son of King Dasaratha, described as a long-armed hero who performs morning devotions and resides in a hermitage with his wife Sita and brother Lakshmana [14]. In Aranya Kanda, Chapter 18, Rama restrains Shurpanakha when she advances towards Sita with malicious intent [15]. 

In Aranya Kanda, Chapter 26, Rama is the virtuous warrior who faces and defeats numerous titans including Dushana and Khara, showcasing exceptional archery skills and unwavering determination [16]. According to Aranya Kanda, Chapter 37, Rama is described as a powerful warrior and archer who destroyed the Titan colony at Janasthana, killing Khara and Dushana [17]. In Aranya Kanda, Chapter 47, Rama is described as the husband of Sita whom she calls out for while being abducted by Ravana [18]. 

In Sundara Kanda, Chapter 1, Rama is the prince whose purpose Hanuman seeks to fulfill by finding his abducted wife, Sita [19]. According to Sundara Kanda, Chapter 58, Rama is the husband of Sita, and Hanuman reflects on Sita's inability to live without him [20]. In Sundara Kanda, Chapter 67, Rama is the valiant prince and beloved husband of Sita, whom she calls upon in her lament, expressing her faith in his eventual rescue [21]. 

In Yuddha Kanda, Chapter 101, Rama uses the Gandharva Weapon to decimate Ravana's forces and restore order [22]. According to Yuddha Kanda, Chapter 111, Rama defeats Ravana using a powerful weapon given to him by the sage Agastya [23]. In Yuddha Kanda, Chapter 112, Rama consoles Bibishana, explaining that warriors who die fighting for their duty should not be mourned excessively and instructs him to perform the funeral rites [24]. 

In Uttara Kanda, Chapter 109, Rama leads a grand procession to the Sarayu River for the Mahaprasthana, carrying Kusha Grass and accompanied by various deities and beings [25]. According to Uttara Kanda, Chapter 110, Rama ascends to heaven with his brothers after stepping into the sacred waters of Sarayu [26].
